seriesJson.title: And the world listened
seriesJson.description: This series presents dramatizations of famous speeches.

node.title: Franklin Delano Roosevelt: Four freedoms
node.description: Franklin Delano Roosevelt and the Four Freedoms.

node.title: Winston Churchill: Battle of Britain
node.description: This program focuses on Winston Churchill and the protection of the home land and the survival of freedom.

node.title: Elizabeth Cady Stanton: Property rights
node.description: Elizabeth Cady Stanton and the fight for the right of women to hold property after marriage.

node.title: Booker T. Washington: Atlanta International Exposition
node.description: Booker T. Washington and his speech at the Atlanta International Exposition.

node.title: Abraham Lincoln: Lincoln-Douglas debate
node.description: This program focuses on Abraham Lincoln and his debated with Stephen Douglas.

node.title: Daniel Webster: Knapp murder trial
node.description: On Daniel Webster and the trial of Frank Knapp for the murder of Captain White of Salem.

node.title: Daniel O'Connell: Irish independence
node.description: More than a million people were said to have gathered at Tara in Ireland on Aug. 15, 1843, to hear Daniel O'Connell speak for Irish independence.

node.title: Edmund Burke: Conciliation with America
node.description: A dramatization of Edmund Burke's speech asserting that taxation and representation are inseparably conjoined.

node.title: William Pitt: The attempt to subjugate America
node.description: William Pitt's speeches concern liberty, government by constitution, and the misery of war.

node.title: Peter Wentworth: Freedom of speech
node.description: Peter Wentworth's speech to the Commons in 1576 in the Parliament is the first extended discourse on freedom of speech.  It earned him a stay in the Tower of London.

node.title: Cicero: First Philippic
node.description: Cicero - First Philippic. Concerned with the retention of the Republic and with the liberty and freedom of Roman citizens.

node.title: Demosthenes: Second Cheronese
node.description: Demosthenes - Second Cheronese.  A strong plea for collective security, for halting aggression by a power whose aggressiveness may ultimately be turned against Athens.

node.title: Pericles: Funeral address
node.description: Pericles - Funeral Address. This speech, akin to the Gettysburg Address, is the prototype of funeral addresses on national ceremonial occasions. Delivered at a critical moment in Athens' history.
